reporter_caption.center: COM. ex rel. THOMPSON v. HENDRICK, 202 Pa. Super. 29 (1963)

caption.center: Commonwealth ex rel. Thompson, Appellant v. Hendrick.

opinion.syllabus:
Criminal Law — Practice — Habeas corpus — Alleged illegalconfinement for assault and battery — Commitment on othercharges — Evidence.
In a habeas corpus proceeding, in which it appeared that petitioner, who had been committed to the county prison on a charge of assault and battery, alleged that he had been attacked by certain persons, but that he, himself, had been held by the magistrate on a charge of assault and battery, that petitioner also included a motion to nol. pros., and that petitioner further complained of injuries imposed upon him at the hands of the police, the magistrate, and a bondsman; that petitioner failed to state that he was being held not only on the one charge of assault and battery, but also on two other separate and distinct charges, for one of which bail had been entered and withdrawn; and that the court below, holding, in the circumstances, that even if the petition were pertinent, petitioner's confinement was not illegal, and that the main thrust of defendant's petition was to avoid trial, dismissed the petition; it was Held that the order of the court below should be affirmed.
opinion.panel: Before RHODES, P.J., ERVIN, WRIGHT, WOODSIDE, WATKINS, MONTGOMERY, and FLOOD, JJ.
opinion.posture:
Appeal, No. 210, Oct. T., 1963, from order of Court of Common Pleas No. 1 of Philadelphia County, March T., 1963, No. 3085, in case of Commonwealth ex rel. Alphonso Thompson v. Edward J. Hendrick, Superintendent. Order affirmed.
Same case in court below: 31 Pa. D. C. 2d 496.
Habeas corpus.
Order entered dismissing petition, opinion by CARROLL, P.J. Petitioner appealed.
